lines.content: * Fork this repo to your GitHub account and clone the fork to your computer
1. Open IntelliJ (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project dialog first).
1. Set up the correct JDK version.
* Click `Configure` > `Structure for new Projects` (in older versions of Intellij:`Configure` > `Project Defaults` > `Project Structure`).
* If JDK 11 is listed in the drop down, select it. If it is not, click `New...` and select the directory where you installed JDK 11.
1. Locate the project directory and click `OK`.
1. Select `Create project from existing sources` and click `Next`.
1. Rename the project if you want. Click `Next`.
1. Ensure that your src folder is checked. Keep clicking `Next`.

→ [Part 1: Introduction to JavaFX][fx1]
→ [Part 2: Creating a GUI for Driver.duke.Duke][fx2]
→ [Part 3: Interacting with the user][fx3]
→ [Part 4: Introduction to FXML][fx4]
* If you have feedback or bug reports, please post in [se-edu/duke issue tracker](https://github.com/se-edu/duke/issues).

// Change this to your main class.
E-1337 is a Personal Assistant Chatbot which stores and records your to-dos, deadlines, events, and loans.
This User Guide will demonstrate how to use its capabilities, such that users will have a smooth and productive
- Simply open the .jar file on your computer/machine to launch the program.
- Upon creating an entry or updating any Tasks, a separate file will be created so that you can
refer to it outside of the program.
Note: this file will be used for subsequent launches of the program, hence any edits will be reflected the next launch.
Note: Should this file be absent, a new empty file will be created in its place.
There are 4 types of Tasks that E-1337 can process. These include:
The `help` command provides the users with a list of instructions on how to use the chatbot.
- Adding a Task requires users to know what kind of Task they would like to add. Here, users can choose
from ToDo, Deadline, Event, or Loan. Below are some provided examples.
The format for adding Tasks is as follows:
For ToDo Tasks, simply type `todo` and the Task name.
- Say there was a ToDo Task called Good to be recorded.
For Deadline Tasks, `/by` separates the Task name and the deadline of completion.
- Say there was a Deadline Task called Software Engineering Project, due 6 April 2019.
For Event Tasks, `/at` separates the Task name and the date of the Event.
- Say there was an Event Task called Samuel's Birthday Party happening on 5 May 2019.
For Loan Tasks, `/value` separates the name of the other party and the value involved.
- Say that a Loan was made to Judy with a value of $18 worth.
To list down all Tasks that have been recorded, simply use the command `list`.
Should the list of Tasks be empty, running the `list` command gives the outcome below.
To indicate a Task has been Done, we simply use `done <index number>`.
- `[V]` denotes a Task as Complete, while `[X]` denotes a Task as Incomplete.
- Note: The `index number` would be the same we obtain from performing a `list` command.
- Given that a Loan to Judy worth $18 has an index number of 4, as seen in the section for the list command,
E-1337 can help find Tasks by keywords, regardless if the kaywords entered are full or partial, uppercase or lowercase.
To do so, simply use the `find <keyword>` command.
- Suppose we want to find any Task containing the variant of 'good' from the list shown.
- Performing the `find good` command provides the desired outcome.
To delete Tasks, simply perform the `delete <index>` command.
- Note: `<index>` can be a single number, a sequence of space-separated numbers, or 'all'.
- Suppose we wanted to delete the Task with index 4, which is the Loan to Judy.
We can also **delete Multiple Tasks** with their index number specified.
- Suppose we wanted to Delete Tasks 3 (Samuel's Birthday Party) and 5 (GooD) from the list.
We can also delete the **entire list** using `delete all`.
- Suppose we wanted to delete all the Tasks in the list.
Besides clicking the Close Window button, E-1337 also facilitates exiting the program via chat.
To do so, simply use the `bye` command, which E-1337 responds with a farewell greeting, before exiting in `3 seconds`.
- Note: Upon exit, should there have been any changes (addition, removal, update) of Tasks, a file (LastSavedTasks.txt)
- LastSavedTasks.txt stores the previous session's Tasks to be loaded the next time the application is launched.
- Should you like to export your Tasks, E-1337 recommends making a copy of it rather than removing it.
The project uses references from tutorials by Jeffry Lum (@j-lum) for JavaFX.

* User Interface class which is centred about a strong user experience and its associated methods.
* Mainly uses public static methods to format Strings for easy identification and usage.
* Gives the String to greet the user with instructions on how to use Duke.
* @return String to greet the user with instructions on how to use Duke.
return "Hello, E-1337 here! :D I am an android crafted specifically "
+ "by my inventor Eugene to help you humans out with your memory.\n"
+ "I'm feeling good and ready to go! What can I do for you today?\n"
+ "If you're unsure, here are some things I can do:\n"
+ "5. List all your Tasks and Loans\n"
+ "If you're unfamiliar on how to use me, try entering 'help'\n";
* Gives the String to say farewell to the user, for now.
* @return String to say farewell to the user, for now.
return "====> Alright byeee thanks for coming and see ya soon! <==== \n:D :D :D :D :D\n"
+ "Please exit by clicking the big red X button, or I'll close it for you soon.";
* Gives the String to provide the user with instructions on how to use Duke.
* @return String of instructions on how to use Duke.
return "Here, you can do the following:\n"
+ "1. todo <task name> (adds a Task to do)\n"
+ "2. event <event name> /at <event date> (adds an event with a date)\n"
+ "3. deadline <deadlined task name> /by <deadline date> (adds a task with a deadline)\n"
+ "6. done <task number> (marks task labelled <task number> as done)\n"
+ "7. delete <task number> (deletes task labelled <task number> from the list) or simply delete all\n"
+ "8. find <keywords separated by space> (finds the tasks in the list with the keyword(s)) "
+ "Note that all dates follow the format YYYY-MM-DD\n"
+ "PS: A '[V]' indicates a completed task while a '[X]' indicates an incomplete task";

* @return String indicating removal of a given Task, of its index then and the current number of Tasks remaining.
public static String taskRemovalMessage(Task removedTask, TaskList allTasks) {
+ "\nHope it's worth it!\nYou are now left with " + allTasks.sizeOf() + " tasks.";

+ "The format for the time/date should be 'YYYY-MM-DD' or 'YYYY/MM/DD'\n"

* Provides a custom String representation of the current Exception, which includes formatting lines.

* Exception when done command has an issue.
* Provides a custom String representation of the current Exception, which includes formatting lines.
return "Seems like you are kinda tired. Please remember to define a Task Number!\n"
+ "Or, you could also take a break. :)";
* The most general Exception in the Duke Program, of which other Exceptions are child classes of.
* Constructor for DukeException, parent exception of all exceptions in Duke program.
* Exception when the TaskList is empty but an unexpected action is commanded by the user.
* Provides a custom String representation of the current Exception, which includes formatting lines.
return "No tasks! You're good to go!\nPlease exit using 'bye' command. :)";
* Exception when event command has an issue.
* Provides a custom String representation of the current Exception, which includes formatting lines.
return "Event tasks should be named/specified with time duration, Blur! XD\n"
+ "The format for the time/date should be 'YYYY-MM-DD' or 'YYYY/MM/DD'\n"
* Exception when inputs of user are unclear, prompting for clearer input.
* Provides a custom String representation of the current Exception, which includes formatting lines.
return "I'm not quite sure I understand you :(\n"
+ "Please enter another command, this time, with "
+ "You can try typing 'help' if you're unsure!";
* Exception when loan command has issue.
* Provides a custom String representation of the current Exception, which includes formatting lines.
return "Loans should be tagged with someone's name and a value.\n"
* Exception when to do command has issue.
* Provides a custom String representation of the current Exception, which includes formatting lines.
return "Please enter another todo command, this time, with "

* Standard task to be done without time limit or specific time of happening.

* Gives a message indicating that the To-Do Task has been added.
* @return String indicating that the To-Do Task has been added.
return "==> Added unique ToDo task: " + this;

TaskList tl = new TaskList(); // new TaskList to store Tasks
